entries.meaning: comparative form of blind: more blind

examples: As it was, innocence was his blinder.

entries.meaning: A bag or cloth put over the head of a difficult horse while it is being handled or mounted.
A screen attached to a horse's bridle preventing it from being able to see things to its side.
examples: From both sides of his head a blackness swiftly grew like blinders on a horse and darkly narrowed his field of vision.
He played a blinder this afternoon on the cricket ground.

entries.meaning: (slang) A bout of heavy drinking, a bender.
examples: If a man goes out on a blinder, he might be charged with being drunk and incapable and therefore have a criminal record, although he is an honourable man.

entries.meaning: (theater) A bright light used to blind the audience temporarily during a scene change.
examples: When the 'blinders' are switched off, and the audience's eyes given time to re-adjust, the new scene is in place  […]

verbs.description: blinder (third-person singular simple present blinders, present participle blindering, simple past and past participle blindered)

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative, by extension) To obstruct the vision of.
examples: […]  We climb in hopes / Of such seeing up the leaf-shuttered escarpments, / Blindered by green, under a green-grained sky
